table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the sound, and not to any letter or glyph.

table.name: mem
table.column: In other words, "upload" (or possibly "download", depending on context).

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also be used to express "feature" in the sense used in software.[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: A patron at a {Qe':n} may {lajQo':v:nolink} a dish if the {jabwI':n} has {qawHa':v}.[1, p.102]

table.name: mem
table.column: Mary had a little "lamb", and its fleece was not white as snow.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb can be used with the suffix {-chu':v} to express the idea of superimposing something on(to) something else.[2] See {tIr:v}.
In the printed booklet for {qep'a' 26 (2019):src}, there was a typo and {lanchu':sen:nolink} was incorrectly written as {lalchu':sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: row or line (of people or things expected to be in motion)

This would be used for a queue, i.e., a line of people waiting to get into a movie. It is expected that the row or line of people or things is (or will or might be) in motion, so that eventually it diminishes until it's gone (in contrasted to a {wIyqap:n} which is stationary). This word is used even if the people or things are bunched up. If there are two rows of people waiting to get into two side-by-side entrances, {lanSoy:n:nolink} would still be used for each of them (and not {wev:n}).
The word {mIr:n:1} can be used as a slang term for this, if things are clear.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Something that is "long" is usually thin.
This was defined as "be thin" in {TKD:src} and expanded to include "be narrow" at {qep'a' 25 (2018):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is to vote in an election or to vote for a motion. It doesn't have the idiomatic sense of "express an opinion" and is only used if a formal vote is actually taken.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb describes movement like that of a bird's wings, and not like that of a flag (for which see {joq:v}). In flight, a bird's wings {laq:v:1:nolink}, and the bird is said to {laqmoH@@laq:v:1, -moH:v} its wings.
The example comes from the KLI website and not from the {HolQeD:src} article itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: The non-slang way to say this would be {jat Hol jatlh:sen@@jat Hol:n, jatlh:v}.
The English idiom "flap one's gums" means to talk meaninglessly.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is matter produced by an infected wound.[1]
One of the meanings of {puS:v:1} is "several".

table.name: mem
table.column: ink up, put paint on a brush

This is used both for the act of transferring ink from a {rItlh 'echlet:n} to a {toqwIn:n}, and the act of putting paint on a {rItlh naQ:n}.
A slang term for this action is {pID:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is defined only as "shrine" in {KGT:src}. The definition "monument, memorial (building)" was added at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}.
In English slang, a "lat"rine is sometimes called a "shrine".

table.name: mem
table.column: The suffix for the plural of this word depends on whether it is used to refer to beings capable of language (see {-pu':n:suff}), body parts (see {-Du':n:suff}), or things which are neither (see {-mey:n:suff}).

The English translation of the sentence from {Star Trek Constellations:src} does not appear in the book, but in the author's annotations which was a separate document. The Klingon sentence was printed with a typo in the book, a space after {qIrq:n:name}. It's clear that {-'e':n:suff} was intended since the English translation fronts "Kirk": "Kirk I want alive" (as opposed to "I want Kirk alive").

table.name: mem
table.column: Pour the cold bloodwine into another glass!
This idiomatic expression means "I don't believe you, maybe someone else will", or "That is irrelevant to me, maybe someone else will care."

table.name: mem
table.column: Less formally, one could end the list of things by saying {latlh latlh latlh:sen@@latlh:n, latlh:n, latlh:n} or {taH taH taH:sen@@taH:v:1, taH:v:1, taH:v:1}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: People often just use a shrub when they can't find a "lav"atory.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This means to move to a slanted or angled position. The starting position is often, but doesn't have to be, upright or perpendicular. If applied to a person, it means the person's feet stay put. The pivot could be at the top, bottom, or somewhere else.
Returning to the upright (or earlier) position is {lavHa':v@@lav:v, -Ha':v}.
If the swinging is continuously back and forth, use {ler:v} instead.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a traditional (in the sense of having been used a long time ago but no longer in use today) unit of angle. There are 243 {lawmey:n:nolink} in a {gho:n}. (Note that 243 is 3 to the 5th power.)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a modern unit of angle adopted from other civilizations in the galaxy. It is also referred to as a {law chu':n:nolink} (although that term is used less and less). There are 360 {lawrI'mey:n:nolink} in a {gho:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The word {law':v:nolink} is used in comparative constructions. See {... X law' ... X puS:sen}.
For things that are measurable or quantifiable, but not necessarily countable, use {vItlh:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This construction is used to form comparatives and superlatives. The two things being compared go into the two slots. To form the superlative, {Hoch:n} is used in the second slot.[1]
Other antonym pairs may be substituted in place of {law':v} and {puS:v:1} as a form of word play, an example of intentional ungrammaticality. Such an advanced construction should be avoided unless one is very familiar with Klingon culture.[2]
To say that something is not more {X:sen:nolink} than something else, {law'be':v:nolink} and {puSbe':v:nolink} are used instead of {law':v:nolink} and {puS:v:nolink}. To say that something is as {X:sen:nolink} as something else, {law':v:nolink} is used with {law':v:nolink} (if the quality or its possession is considered positive), or {puS:v:nolink} is used with {puS:v:nolink} (if the quality or its possession is considered negative), or {law':v:nolink} is used with {rap:v} or {nIb:v} (the latter of which implies the two things being compared are exactly the same in some way). It is also possible to use {puS:v:nolink} with {rap:v} or {nIb:v}, but that carries a connotation of disparagement. To say that something is not as {X:sen:nolink} as something else, {pIm:v} is used in place of the second verb in the pair.[3]
To say that two things have the same amount of some quality, it's also possible to use {rap:v} or {nIb:v} without a {law':v:nolink}/{puS:v:nolink} construction. (See those verbs for details.)
The above constructions are typically used only to compare similar things. To form similes, which compare things which are unlike, use {rur:v} instead. When the above constructions are used to compare unlike things, they generally reference well-known similes.

In the 1st edition of the {paq'batlh:src}, the sentence had been {SoH rallaw' law' Hoch rallaw' puS.:sen:nolink} This was changed to put the {-law':v} on the antonym pair {law':v:nolink} and {puS:v:nolink} in the 2nd edition.
[1] {TKD 6.6:src}, [2] {KGT p.178-9:src}, [3] {HQ 13.1, p.8-10, Mar. 2004:src}, [4] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2015:src}, [5] {Smithsonian GO FLIGHT app:src}, [6] {paq'batlh 2ed p.130-131:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This is some sort of technical term. It would be odd to say {lay vItlhuH:sen@@lay:n:2, vI-:v, tlhuH:v:1} for "I breathe air", but it would be understood.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column:
This is the 6th rank of {yaS:n}.[2]
Do not confuse this with {ra'wI':n}, which is also translated as "commander" in English, but has a different meaning.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Ferengi Alliance.

table.name: mem
table.column: The {la'quv:n:nolink} is head of the Klingon High Council, and the highest ranked {yaS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a Klingon creature that resembles a Terran turtle, which might be called a {tera' la'SIv:n:nolink}.
Source is an e-mail from MO to loghaD.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an officer in charge of certain specialized units within the military.

table.name: mem
table.column: The object of this verb is the victim of blackmail.

When someone's a "lech", they may be subject to blackmail.
The object was confirmed during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: be perpendicular, be at a right angle
This is normally used with a plural subject.
A plumb bob is often made of lead.
▶ {leD rav tlhoy' je@@leD:v, rav:n:1, tlhoy':n, je:conj} "The floor and the wall are perpendicular (to each other)."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: A sharp knife is nothing without a sharp eye.

table.name: mem
table.column: For the removal of something from the exterior, consider {teq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The inhabitants of Lenmak use an eight-day week ({Hogh:n}).
This is a reference to John Lennon and Paul McCartney. The names of the days of the week are all references to the Beatles.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a disease caused by a bacterium. Its symptoms include high fever, weakness, and perhaps abdominal pain, headaches, and a skin rash. Klingons tend to avoid talking about it.[1]

This was requested as a native Klingon equivalent for typhoid fever.
Probably a coincidence: Lieven Lemnes was the author of "Diseases: Their Symptoms and Cures".

table.name: mem
table.column:
{leng:v:nolink} works like {jaH:v}.[2]
This word can be used to refer to traveling with or without a special purpose. If it is desired to indicate traveling on a mission, use {ve':v} instead.[3]

▶ {yuQ vIleng.:sen:nolink} or {yuQDaq vIleng.:sen:nolink} "I travel to the planet."[2] ▶ {yuQvo' jIleng.:sen:nolink} "I roam away from the planet."[2] ▶ {yuQDaq jIleng.:sen:nolink} "I roam around/about on the planet."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This may be applied to any meal, e.g., {leng megh:n:nolink} "voyage lunch" (see {megh:n}). See {KGT p.103:src} for a fuller explanation.
takeaway, take-away, take away, takeout, take-out, take out

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also refer to a button, such as on an {'eQway':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This describes the back-and-forth motion of something fixed at one end to a pivot. When applied to a person, it means the feet stay put on the ground while the body leans left and right.[1] The pivot could be at the top, bottom, or somewhere else. A rhythmic oscillation like that of a pendulum would be {lerchu':v}.[2]
For motion around a pivot in one direction only, which comes to a stop, see {lav:v}.[2]
For movement to the side without rotation or being fixed to a point, see {Dav:v:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the rhythmic back-and-forth motion of something fixed at one end, like a pendulum, whether the pivot is at the top, the bottom (like the inverted pendulum of a metronome), or somewhere else.
For another example where {-chu':v} on a verb of motion indicates a rhythmic pattern, see {jaDchu':v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Purell" is a brand of hand sanitiser.

table.name: mem
table.column: The fact that this is homophonous with {leS:v} may have to do with how many "rests" (sleeps) one gets before the day in question. Note that {Hu':n:nolink} is also homohonous with {Hu':v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a type of {HurDagh:n}. It is larger than the {Supghew:n} but smaller than the {tIngDagh:n}.
Les Paul was an American guitarist, after whom the Gibson Les Paul electric guitar was named.

table.name: mem
table.column:
For "be hard (be difficult)", see {Qatlh:v}.
This word can be used figuratively. There is an idiom, {let mInDu'Daj; Separmey rur@@let:v, mIn:n, -Du':n, -Daj:n, Separ:n, -mey:n, rur:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the metallic chemical element with the symbol Hg and atomic number 80.
Read backwards, this is {ngIb tel:n@@ngIb:n:1, tel:n} "ankle wings", a reference to the talaria (winged sandals) of the god Mercury.

table.name: mem
table.column: The stairway leading to door of a ship is referred to by a more specific word, {choghvat:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: stairway leading to door of a ship
In some {meqro'vaq Sep:n} dialects, this refers to what is elsewhere called a {choghvat:n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The soft palate is known as the "vel"um.

table.name: mem
table.column: move bat'leth from vertical to horizontal orientation

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used for flowers, but can also be used for leaves.[1]
A reference to stage actor Lew Bloom.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word for nose is {ghIch:n} everywhere, but in some regions this word is used as an alternative.[1, p.28]
The regions where this word is used are not specified in {KGT:src}.[1, p.28]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used in the sense of "general" (as opposed to specific). For example, {nav HablI' le'be'} might refer to the general or shared fax machine at the front desk of an office, as opposed to a fax machine at someone's desk.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A reference to a famous scene from Les Miserables.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This is one possible verb to use with {watrIn:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: travel or move a specified or measurable distance or trajectory
The object of this verb is the distance or range of motion. It is used with movement verbs such as {ron:v:1}.

▶ {ron SuvwI'; chorgh 'ujmey lID:sen@@ron:v:1, SuvwI':n, chorgh:n:1, 'uj:n, -mey:n, lID:v} or {chorgh 'ujmey lID SuvwI'; ron:sen@@chorgh:n:1, 'uj:n, -mey:n, lID:v, SuvwI':n, ron:v:1} "the warrior rolled (haphazardly) for eight ujes" ▶ {ron muD Duj; javmaH lawrI'mey lID:sen@@ron:v:2, muD Duj:n, jav:n:1, maH:n:2, lawrI':n, -mey:n, lID:v} "the airplane rolled 60 degrees"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used for passengers only, and would not be used for "riding" a bicycle, for example.[3]
That this verb is used for passengers only was clarified during the Q & A session at {qep'a' 28 (2021):src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also called {lIghonya':n:nolink}, typically by older speakers.[1, p.141-142]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is often pronounced as if it were {lIghongan:n:nolink}[1, p.141]

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to begin to sing a song (the singer is the subject and the song is the object).[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The idea is that the subject of the verb looks or behaves like something (or someone) else or represents something (or someone) else. Like {ghet:v}, it has no connotation of fraud or anything underhanded. The object is the thing being simulated or the person being impersonated.
The lowercase "L" and uppercase "I" look alike and are often confused when Klingon is written in a sans serif typeface.
▶ {'IDnar pIn'a' lIl:sen@@'IDnar pIn'a':n, lIl:v} "he/she impersonates a wizard (non-fraudulently)"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is something (or someone) which looks or behaves like something (or someone) else. A {lIlwI':n:nolink} is different from a {lIw:n} since {lIw:n:nolink} implies replacement, whereas a {lIlwI':n:nolink} doesn't replace anyone or anything.

table.name: mem
table.column:
When {A:sen:nolink} and {B:sen:nolink} share {C:sen:nolink} with each other, the construction is {C lulIn A B je:sen:nolink} (or {C lIn A B je:sen:nolink} if {C:sen:nolink} is plural). In this case, the speaker is non-committal about whether {A:sen:nolink} or {B:sen:nolink} is the one who decided to do the sharing with the other.[1]
When a computer (or computer system) is online, it's said to be "sharing". See {lIn:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is just the application of {lIn:v:1} to a computer networking context. Klingons think of a computer (or computer system) which is online as "sharing".

On"lin"e.
The definition was not given. It's just explained that going online would use the verb {lIn:v:2,nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression is not a euphemism, but is a little risque. It means that the subjects have a physical relationship of some sort.

table.name: mem
table.column: The definition was not given. It's just explained that going offline would use the verb {lInHa':v:nolink}.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This was confirmed to mean to cause to gather in one place, as with prisoners or livestock.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This means being stuck like when you can't solve an algebra problem or a crossword puzzle.
To "be licked" is to be soundly defeated by something.

table.name: mem
table.column: Edward Lear was the author of the poem "The Owl and the Pussycat".

table.name: mem
table.column: [1] {DSC - Battle at the Binary Stars:src}, [2] {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2019:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This animal is more rat-sized than mouse-sized, but a {vIghro':n} might well chase it. Its face kind of resembles that of a bat (though a bat is not a rodent).[1]
Basil is the name of the titular mouse in the Disney movie The Great Mouse Detective. Also, the final episode of Fawlty Towers is titled "Basil the Rat".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {jol SeHlaw lItHa'!@@jol SeHlaw:n, lItHa':v} "Get off that transporter control panel!"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is something constructed to hold a door or gate, whether a door or gate is there or not.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a group of igneous rocks composed primarily of feldspar and quartz.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a temporary substitute or stand-in. To denote a permanent replacement, use {qa'meH:n}.[2] To refer to something or someone which simulates or impersonates something or someone else, without replacement, see {lIlwI':n}.[4]

This is a substitute in "lieu" of something.
This was used to refer to "variables" (a memory location used for storing data in a computer program) in Klingon Blockly.[3]
[1] {KGT:src}, [2] {HQ 5.1, Mar. 1996 p.10:src}, [3] {KLI mailing list 2014.11.26:src}, [4] {KLI mailing list 2016.11.25:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: This applies to full words only, not prefixes (which are {moHaq:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column:
The cultural connotations are a bit different than the English word "concubine". In Klingon culture, everything associated with a {lIwnal:n:nolink} lacks honor, which is not necessarily the case for a (Terran) king's concubines or courtesans.
Only married people could have a partner who could be considered a {lIwnal:n:nolink}. A {lIwnal:n:nolink} could be male or female, so if it's necessary to distinguish, use {loD lIwnal:n@@loD:n, lIwnal:n} or {be' lIwnal:n@@be':n, lIwnal:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This could mean "download" or "upload", depending on the context.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a state of matter.
LCD and plasma are both types of flatscreen television technologies.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to hair on the upper lip.[2]
The loach is a species of fish with barbels which look like a mustache.

table.name: mem
table.column: be a fraction of, make up a portion of, constitute part of

This is used to express fractions in math.
If appropriate in a mathematical discussion, no prefix is used even if the denominator is one, even though this is a bit grammatically aberrant. (One would not say {wa' luloch wej:sen@@wa':n:num, lu-:v, loch:v, wej:n:num}.)[1]

▶ {wej loch cha':sen@@wej:n:num, loch:v, cha':n:num} "2/3" ▶ {vagh loch wej:sen@@vagh:n:1,num, loch:v, wej:n:num} "3/5" ▶ {loS loch jav:sen@@loS:n:1,num, loch:v, jav:n:1,num} "6/4" ▶ {wa' loch wej:sen@@wa':n:num, loch:v, wej:n:num} "3/1"

table.name: mem
table.column: The suffix for the plural of this word depends on whether it is used to refer to beings capable of language (see {-pu':n:suff}) or not (see {-mey:n:suff}).

table.name: mem
table.column: I am not a merry man.

table.name: mem
table.column: A "brother-in-law" is {loDnI' loDnal:n@@loDnI':n, loDnal:n} or {be'nI' loDnal:n@@be'nI':n, loDnal:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In Klingon, "deep space" is called {logh Hop:n}, literally, "far space".[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is appended to a number to form an adverbial meaning that many times. For example, {wa'logh:adv} "once, one time" from {wa':n:num} "one", {cha'logh:adv} "twice, two times" from {cha':n:num} "two", and so on.

table.name: mem
table.column: loghDaq Suvrupbogh SuvwI'pu' chaH Hoch SuvwI'pu''e'.
In space, all warriors are cold warriors.
The expression "cold war" in English refers to a conflict without actual fighting, but in which each side is prepared to begin fighting at any time.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a Federation space station.
{SkyBox 99:src} had only the Klingon text. The English and German text come from {SkyBox 01:src} and {SkyBox 95:src}, respectively, which were just translations into those languages of the same card.

▶ {loS... qIb HeHDaq, 'u' SepmeyDaq Sovbe'lu'bogh lenglu'meH He ghoSlu'bogh retlhDaq 'oHtaH. HaDlu'meH, QuSlu'meH, SuDlu'meH lojmIt Da logh Hop Hut tengchaH. vaj loghDaq lenglaHtaH Humanpu'. veH Qav 'oH logh'e'.:sen:nolink} "It waits... on the edge of the galaxy, beside a passage to unknown regions of the universe, space station Deep Space Nine is the gateway for the exploration, intrigue and enterprise that mark the continuation of the human adventure into space - the final frontier."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a line in "Lady Madonna" by The Beatles: "Thursday night your stockings needed mending." (See {paSlogh:n}.)

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the upper front of the torso.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is an extension of {logh'ob:n:1} to the front of other things, in which case the back would be {Sa'Hut:n:2} and the sides would be {reD:n:3}.[1] In this usage, the plural is formed with {-mey:n:suff}.[2]
This can apply to cars, motorcycles, space ships and the like, but not to the front of a computer screen (too flat) or a bottle (because it's round). There's an overlap with {'et:n:2h}, but whereas {'et:n:2h,nolink} refers to a 3-dimensional space, {logh'ob:n:2,nolink} refers to the surface at the front.[3]

An explanation of {logh'ob:n:2,nolink}, {Sa'Hut:n:2,nolink}, and {reD:n:3,nolink} was given during the Q & A session at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2021:src}.
This was defined as "front". The clarification "exterior surface" was added based on the explanation.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the central processing unit of a computer.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used for something that incrementally or gradually (not necessarily slowly) goes away, such as food on one's plate or dirt that one washes off of something.[2]
If a room is filled with boxes that are to be taken somewhere, and then over a short or long time, the boxes are removed, then {loj:v:nolink} could be used once there are no more boxes. If a room was full of furniture, and a person left the room and came back to find the room empty (and there was no reason to expect this to happen), then {ngab:v} might be used.[2]
This word would be appropriate to describe what happens to someone who beams away, if one is focusing on the incremental disappearance of the person. Once the person is gone, {ngab:v:nolink} might be used. People who are watching someone beam away might use {DemchoH:v@@Dem:v, -choH:v} to describe what they are seeing.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: No one eavesdrops at an open door.

table.name: mem
table.column: {lojmItjaj:n:nolink} tends to be used on formal occasions, while both it and {ghInjaj:n:nolink} are used, seemingly indiscriminately, otherwise.
This refers to a line in "Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!" by The Beatles, which partly goes "on Saturday at Bishopsgate".

table.name: mem
table.column: be in a stance, be in a pose (people, animals, or martial arts)
The verb to use for striking a pose or stance is {much:v:3}.
▶ {lol SuvwI'; mIl'oD much:sen@@lol:v:1, SuvwI':n, mIl'oD:n, much:v:3}

table.name: mem
table.column:
Note that there is a homophonous verb {lol:v:1} which can be applied to people or animals.
Some of the verb suffixes have a precise meaning when used with this verb, when it is applied to aircraft or spacecraft: ▶ {lolchu':v} "be in a correct attitude" ▶ {lolchu'taH:v} "maintain a correct attitude" ▶ {lolmoH:v} "maneuver (an aircraft) to be in an attitude" ▶ {loltaH:v} "maintain an attitude"
In aviation, attitude refers to an aircraft's orientation with respect to the horizon. This should not be confused with altitude, or distance to the ground.

table.name: mem
table.column: a specific position in the martial arts form Mok'bara
This refers to a specific martial arts stance, and is not a general term for "stance", for which see {tonSaw':n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: maneuver (an aircraft) to be in an attitude
▶ {qughmeH Duj vIlolmoH.:sen:nolink} "I put the vessel in the attitude for cruise (or cruising)."

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is plural. Its singular form is unknown. It appears to consist of the elements {lol:v:2}, {SeH:v}, and {cha:n}, or homophones thereof.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was defined as "celebrate" in {TKD:src}. The definition was clarified and narrowed to "observe, celebrate (a ritual)" in {KGT:src}.
[1] {TKD:src}, [2] {KGT:src}, [3] {SkyBox 31:src} (reprinted in {HQ 6.2, p.9, Jun. 1997:src}), [4] {SkyBox 32:src} (reprinted in {HQ 6.2, p.9, Jun. 1997:src}), [5] {Klingon Monopoly:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: party, celebration (a specific type of Klingon party or celebration)
This is an event to which the spirits of ancestors are invited.[2]

The gloss in {KGT:src} says simply "party, celebration". The definition has been changed for clarity based on the information from {KCD:src}. In {KCD:src}, Vok says, "The celebration was declared a {lopno':n:nolink}. You have invited all the spirits of our Klingon ancestors." This suggests that a {lopno':n:nolink} is a type of party or celebration, rather than a specific event.

table.name: mem
table.column: A warrior does not complain about physical discomfort.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to formerly living things, and not, for example, to volcanoes.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to one's mother's brother's child or one's father's sister's child (i.e., "cross-cousins").

table.name: mem
table.column: For a man, this word refers to a child of his sister. For a woman, this word refers to a child of her brother.

table.name: mem
table.column: A female {lor:n:0}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's brother's daughter or one's father's sister's daughter, or a niece in the sense of a man's sister's daughter or a woman's brother's daughter.

table.name: mem
table.column: A male {lor:n:0}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's brother's son or one's father's sister's son, or a nephew in the sense of a man's sister's son or a woman's brother's son.

table.name: mem
table.column: fourth tone of nonatonic musical scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2,nolink}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The verb usually associated with this is {qaS:v}.[1]

"42". Four-two-itous (fortuitous).
Marc Okrand has said that he prefers to call the puns or "Easter Eggs" in the Klingon vocabulary "coincidences".

table.name: mem
table.column: Quadrotriticale is a four-lobed hybridization of wheat (genus Triticum) and rye (genus Secale).

table.name: mem
table.column: This word and {Qugh:n:1h,nolink} are mostly interchangeable. To refer to something that in all likelihood one can't recover from (like the loss of {pIraqSIS:n}), {lot:n:nolink} is better.[2]
Possibly a reference to the Biblical story of Lot.

table.name: mem
table.column: Lottery tickets often come in the form of scratch cards.

table.name: mem
table.column: Reverse of "Geritol", a dietary supplement used to treat anemia which was promoted in the media as a cure for "iron-poor tired blood".

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird that swoops into the water in order to catch food, but cannot swim

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Cardassian Union.

table.name: mem
table.column: have personality, be charismatic, be charming

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "use" in {TKD:src}. In Section 4.2.9 of {TKDA:src}, the definition "make use of" was added.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used for "mode" in the sense of a mode of usage. For example, "night mode" (a mode in software to turn its user interface dark, for use at night) would be {ram lo':n@@ram:n, lo':n}.[2]
This was defined as "use" in {TKDA:src}. The "mode" meaning was explained in a message to the {KLI mailing list:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This preceeds the noun it modifies.
▶ {lo' law' choQ:n:nolink} "utility deck" (see {choQ:n} for the complete example) ▶ {lo' law' lojmIt:n} "utility hatch"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a simple verb in its own right, and not the verb {lo':v} with the suffix {-laH:v}. It's likely that there is a historical connection to the verb plus suffix form.[2]

In Section 4.2.9 of {TKDA:src}, the explanation of {-ghach:v:suff} clearly implies that {lo'laH:v:nolink} is the verb {lo':v:nolink} plus the suffix {-laH:v:nolink}. However, the verb {lo':v:nolink} with the suffix {-laH:v:nolink} does not produce the meaning "be valuable". It's likely that {lo':v:nolink} and {lI':v:1} were mixed up while {TKD:src} was being written, as {lI'laHbe':v@@lI':v:1, -laH:v, -be':v} "cannot be useful" is basically synonymous with "be worthless", which appears as {lo'laHbe':v} in the {TKD:src} word list. Consequently, Section 4.2.9 of {TKDA:src} and the {msn:src} newsgroup message are somewhat contradictory.

table.name: mem
table.column: See {chetvI':n:1} for an idiom related to worthlessness.
See under {lo'laH:v:nolink} for an analysis of this word.

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {lo'laH:v:nolink} for an analysis of this word.

table.name: mem
table.column: See under {lo'laH:v:nolink} for an analysis of this word.

table.name: mem
table.column:
See {pum:v:2} for a literal fall.
{lu qeng:n:name,nolink} "The Fall of Kang" is a famous poem by G'trok.[1, p.107]

table.name: mem
mem
mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {lugh; Sor rur}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used for pulling when the pulling is sudden or done with a jerk. This verb can generally be used where either {Hur:v} or {Hoq:v} might otherwise be used, but not in the case of pulling back a bowstring.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: cause (someone) to confess or reveal a secret

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "fail" in {TKD:src}, and as "lose (not win)" in {KGT:src}. In {HQ 2.4:src} it is explained that these are the same word.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v:nolink}, {Hargh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This looks like "they ride it", but it's probably a coincidence.
This word was suggested by Marc Okrand to translate "asylum" (in the sense of "refuge" or "sanctuary") for the Pittsburgh Art Tour.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: While this is an anatomy term, it can be used for other things, such as wood which has gotten wet.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the Chinese word for "dragon" (龍). MO confirmed at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that this was deliberate.

table.name: mem
table.column: Maltz thought this word was based on a story in Klingon mythology about a {lung:n}, but he didn't recall the details.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the most technical term, but there are also the slang expressions {ghew Duj:n} and {jIrwI' Duj:n}.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: {HIj:v} is used for transporting goods, whereas it seems that {lup:v:nolink} is used for transporting people.

table.name: mem
table.column: The existence of this word is inferred from {lupDujHom:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {nuqDaq lupwI' mIr vItIj?@@nuqDaq:ques, lupwI' mIr:n, vI-:v, tIj:v} "Where is the train station?"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: In the 1ed, the name is written as {luqara:n:nolink} once in the introduction, but is {luqara':n:nolink} (with a final {qaghwI':n}) consistently throughout the text.[1] This is fixed in the 2ed.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word "curfew" comes from the French "cuevrefeu", meaning to cover ({vel:v}) the fire ({qul:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon sentence on {SkyBox 13:src} seems to have dropped some words, since it is ungrammatical.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The Klingon compass has three points, rather than four: {chan:n} (east), {'ev:n} (northwest), and {tIng:n} (southwest).
The areas around an object are its {Dung:n} (area above), {bIng:n} (area below), {retlh:n} (area beside), {tlhop:n:1} (front), and {'em:n} (behind). Something in an object's {retlh:n:nolink} can be on its {poS:n} (left) or its {nIH:n} (right). The area between two objects are their {joj:n} (area between). The area beyond an object is its {Hay:n:2h}.
In standard Klingon, locative nouns follow pronouns, e.g., {jIH tlhop:n:nolink} "in front of me". But in the dialect of the Sakrej region ({Sa'Qej Sep:n}), locative nouns take pronominal possessive suffixes, e.g., {tlhopwIj:n:nolink} "my area in front".[2] However, the directional nouns are an exception to this rule, and take possessive suffixes in every known dialect, e.g., {chanwIj:n:nolink} "east of me, to my east". If the full pronoun is used with a directional noun, the pronoun is emphasized, e.g., {jIH chan:n:nolink} "east of ME, to MY east".[4]
When referring to one's left and right sides, possessive suffixes are used. For example, one might say {nIHwIj ghop:n@@nIH:n, -wIj:n, ghop:n} to refer to their right hand.[5]
The points in between the three cardinal directions are {tIng chan:n:nolink}, {'ev chan:n:nolink}, and either {tIng 'ev:n:nolink} or {'ev tIng:n:nolink}. {chan:n:nolink} always comes second in such a compound.[3]

▶ {veng chanDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt east of the city." ▶ {chan vengDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt in the city in the east." ▶ {veng chan yoSDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt in the city's east (the eastern part of the city)." ▶ {'evmajDaq jIwampu'.:sen:nolink} "I have hunted northwest of here." (Northwest is relative to the speaker's location.) ▶ {Daqvam 'ev jIwampu'.:sen:nolink} "I have hunted northwest of here." (Northwest is relative to a location indicated by the speaker, for example a point on a map.)
[1] {TKDA:src}, [2] {KGT p.24:src}, [3] {s.k 1999.11.21:src} (reprinted in {HQ 8.4, p.6-8, Dec. 1999:src}), [4] {s.k 1999.12.01:src}, [5] {KLI mailing list 2019.08.05:src}

table.name: mem
table.column: Sister of B'Etor and Duras. She is portrayed by the actress {barbara' ma'rIch:n:name}.

▶ {DuraS tuq tlhIngan yejquv patlh luDub 'e' reH lunIDtaH DuraS be'nI'pu' lurSa' be'etor je. ngoQvam luchavmeH ghawran maghpu' be'nI'pu'. woQ luSuqmeH jIjpu' chaH romuluSngan'e' je.:sen:nolink} "The sisters of the House of Duras, Lursa and B'Etor, are constantly seeking a higher standing for the House of Duras within the Klingon High Council. To this end, the sisters have acted against Gowron, going as far as to work with Romulan factions in order to gain power."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be submerged in, immersed in, surrounded by

table.name: mem
table.column: The concept of a "fairy tale" might be expressed as {puq lut:n@@puq:n, lut:n} or {lut rorgh:n@@lut:n, rorgh:v} or {puq lut rorgh:n@@puq:n, lut:n, rorgh:v}.[3]
The translations for "fairy tales" are suggestions only. In particular, it was noted that {SIqnaSwaq:n} would probably not be used to translate this term.[3]
▶ {meb, lut tlhaQ DaSov'a'?} "Guest, do you know any funny stories?"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This was used in the Netflix Klingon-language press release for {DSC:src}, which was written by {Quvar:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is associated sometimes with inattentiveness.[1]

This is a reference to the song "Daydream" by The Lovin' Spoonful.
This was rumoured to have been revealed at {qep'a' 26 (2019):src}, and was confirmed at {qep'a' 27 (2020):src} during the Q & A session.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {lu'lap tlhen:sen@@lu'lap:n, tlhen:v} "(it) produces a beep noise"[1]
